Package com.github.actionfx.core.view.graph

Class ControlWrapper

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.actionfx.core.view.graph.NodeWrapper
      • com.github.actionfx.core.view.graph.ControlWrapper
  • public class ControlWrapper
extends NodeWrapper
    Wrapper around a Control in order to have a unique access to its values.

    This wrapper expects a control configuration properties on the classpath in the following location: 

     /afxcontrolwrapper/.properties
    Example: /afxcontrolwrapper/javafx.scene.control.TextField.properties

    For third party library integration it is also required to wrap the library-specific "selection model", so that it can be accessed like a SelectionModel. This is required for example for integrating ControlsFX and their controls using a "CheckModel".

    In case you need to wrap a third party library "selection model", just create a properties under following location on the classpath: 

      afxcontrolwrapper/.properties
    Inside the properties, specify a single property "wrapperClass" that holds the fully qualified class name of the wrapper that is expected to implement the JavaFX interface SelectionModel.
    Author:
    koster

    • Method Detail

      • of

        public static ControlWrapper of​(javafx.scene.control.Control control)
        Convenient factory method for creating a ControlWrapper instance.

        This method tries to retrieve the ControlWrapper instance from the user properties of the supplied Control. If there is no instance of type ControlWrapper present, a new instance is returned.

        This mechanism ensures that you can work always with the same instance of ControlWrapper for the same instance of a Control. This might be especially desirable, when you added listeners to values and you want to remove all listener again through e.g. removeAllValueChangeListener() without holding a reference to the added listener.

        Parameters:
        control - the control to wrap
        Returns:
        the control wrapper instance

      • supportsMultipleValues

        public boolean supportsMultipleValues()
        Checks, whether the wrapped Control supports multiple values or not. Multiple values are supported for example by a ListView with its getItems() method.
        Returns:
        true, if the control supports multiple values, false otherwise.

      • supportsSelectionModelProperty

        public boolean supportsSelectionModelProperty()
        Checks, whether the control supports a SelectionModel property.
        Returns:
        true, if the control supports a SelectionModel, false otherwise.

      • supportsSelection

        public boolean supportsSelection()
        Checks, whether the control supports a selection of values. This requires that the control exposes a SelectionModel or something that can be wrapped to a SelectionModel.
        Returns:
        true, if the control supports a selection of values, false otherwise.

      • supportsMultiSelection

        public boolean supportsMultiSelection()
        Checks, whether the wrapped Control supports multiple selected values or not.
        Returns:
        true, if the control supports multiple selected values, false otherwise.

      • supportsValue

        public boolean supportsValue()
        Checks, whether the wrapped Control supports a "value" property (e.g. for @TextField that is the TextInputControl.textProperty() as configured in the properties file on classpath /afxcontrolwrapper/javafx.scene.control.TextField.properties).
        Returns:
        true, if a value property is available and accessible, false otherwise.

      • supportsValues

        public boolean supportsValues()
        Checks, whether the wrapped Control supports a "values" property (e.g. for @ChoiceBox that is the ChoiceBox.itemsProperty() as configured in the properties file on classpath /afxcontrolwrapper/javafx.scene.control.ChoiceBox.properties).
        Returns:
        true, if a value property is available and accessible, false otherwise.

      • getSelectionModel

        public <V> javafx.scene.control.SelectionModel<V> getSelectionModel()
        Gets the selection model from the wrapped control. In case the wrapped control does not have a selection model, then null is returned.
        Type Parameters:
        V - the value type
        Returns:
        the selection model, or null, in case the wrapped control does not have a selection model

      • getSelectedValue

        public <V> V getSelectedValue()

        Returns:
        the currently selected value

      • getSelectedValueProperty

        Returns:

      • getSelectedValues

        public <V> javafx.collections.ObservableList<V> getSelectedValues()
        Gets the currently selected values. In case the wrapped Control does not support multiple values (i.e. method #supportsMultiselection() returns false), then a list with one element is returned, while the element is identical to getSelectedValue().
        Returns:
        the selected values

      • getUserValue

        public java.lang.Object getUserValue()
        Gets the user value from the wrapped Control.

        The user value is assumed to be one of the following (entries with higher order are of higher priority):

        • in case the control supports multi-selection, the user value is the list of selected items (e.g. the multi-selection inside a TableView)
        • in case the control supports sinle-selection, the user value is the single selected item (e.g. the single-selection inside a TableView)
        • in case the control supports a single-value, the user value is the single value (e.g. the "text" inside a TextField control)
        • in case the control supports a multi-values, the user value is the list of values
        The first matching rule wins for the extraction of the user value.

        This method considers values selected via a SelectionModel.

      • getValuesOrValue

        public java.lang.Object getValuesOrValue()
        Gets values or the value from the wrapped Control.

        The value is assumed to be one of the following (entries with higher order are of higher priority):

        • in case the control supports a single-value, the user value is the single value (e.g. the "text" inside a TextField control)
        • in case the control supports a multi-values, the user value is the list of values
        The first matching rule wins for the extraction of the value.

        Unlike method getUserValue(), this method does not consider selected values through a SelectionModel.

      • getValueFromObservable

        protected java.lang.Object getValueFromObservable​(javafx.beans.Observable observable)
        Extracts the actual value from the supplied Observable.
        Parameters:
        observable - the observable to extract the value from
        Returns:
        the extracted value

      • getUserValueAsObservable

        public javafx.beans.Observable getUserValueAsObservable()
        Gets the user value as an Observable which is usually either an instance of ObservableValue or of ObservableList. However, it is up to the caller to do type checks on the return value.

        A "user value" is a specifically value set by the user, e.g. by entering text in a text field or by selecting entries in a table view.

        Returns:
        the value as an observable

      • getValueOrValuesAsObservable

        public javafx.beans.Observable getValueOrValuesAsObservable()
        Gets the value as an Observable which is usually either an instance of ObservableValue or of ObservableList. However, it is up to the caller to do type checks on the return value.

        A "value" is either a value set by a user (e.g. text in a text field) or the "items" behind e.g. a list/table view or elements inside a choice/combo box.

        Returns:
        the value as an observable

      • enableMultiSelection

        public void enableMultiSelection()
        Enables multi-selection for the wrapped control. This requires that the control has a selection model property that is of type MultipleSelectionModel. In case this property is not present or has a different type, calling this method has no effect on the wrapped control.

      • setValues

        public <V> void setValues​(javafx.collections.ObservableList<V> valueList)
        Sets the given valueList as "values" to the underlying control. Please note that the underlying control must allow setting an observable list under the "values" attribute.
        Type Parameters:
        V - the value type
        Parameters:
        valueList - the value list to set

      • getConverterProperty

        public javafx.beans.property.ObjectProperty<javafx.util.StringConverter<?>> getConverterProperty()
        Returns the "converter" property of a control. In case this property is not supported, null is returned.
        Returns:
        the "converter" property, or null, in case the property is not supported by the wrapped control

      • hasValueOrValuesSet

        public boolean hasValueOrValuesSet()
        Checks, whether the wrapped control has either values or a value set. Values are e.g. text in a TextField or values in a TableView (even when not selected).
        Returns:
        true, if the wrapped control has values set, false otherwise.

      • hasUserValueSet

        public boolean hasUserValueSet()
        Checks, whether the wrapped control has a value set by the user. User values are e.g. text in a TextField or selected values in a TableView.
        Returns:
        true, if the wrapped control has value set by the user, false otherwise.
